blocks.title: Research Participant Information and Consent Form (scroll down to review and agree to participate)
blocks.ask:
Title of the Study: The Role of Interactive Maps in Popular Media

Principal Investigators
Robert E. Roth, PhD 
375 Science Hall
550 N. Park Street
Madison, WI  53706
Email: reroth@wisc.edu

Meghan Kelly
Email: mkelly22@wisc.edu

Nick Lally
Email: nlally@wisc.edu

Description of Research
You are invited to participate in a study aimed at improving interactive web maps. Specifically, the study investigates how interactive maps are used in news stories.

What will my participation involve?
If you decide to participate in this research, you will review two different case studies that include interactive maps. With each case study, you will be given a task to complete. After completing each task, you will respond to a survey of questions related to the case study, task, and the interactive map. The survey will take approximately 30 minutes to complete. You will be compensated $3 for your participation upon completing the survey.

Are there any risks to me?
Risk to participation is minimal. The case studies and interactive maps in this survey cover current news topics with no more detail than news outlets like the New York Times, for example. There are no foreseeable physical or mental risks to participation beyond those encountered in the normal course of everyday life.

Are there any benefits to me?
Your responses to the survey will be used to develop a better understanding of the design of interactive maps.

How will my confidentiality be protected?
No personally identifiable or sensitive information will be collected or maintained. Only group characteristics will be reported in publications of research findings.

Whom should I contact if I have questions?
You may ask any questions about the research at any time. Contact Robert E. Roth, PhD (PI) at reroth@wisc.edu if you have any questions about the research. If you are not satisfied with response of research team, have more questions, or want to talk with someone about your rights as a research participant, you should contact the Education Research and Social & Behavioral Science IRB Office at 608-263-2320. Your participation is completely voluntary and you can withdraw from the study at any time without compensation.

If you do NOT agree to take part in this research study as outline above, please Exit this survey.

If you agree to take part in this research study as outlined above, please click 'Next' below. By selecting 'Next' you agree to the following statement: I understand my rights as a participant and agree to participate in this research Study

blocks.title: Overview, Eligibility, and Instructions (scroll down to review and continue)
blocks.ask:
Thank you for agreeing to participate!

Maps are used on a daily basis at unprecedented levels. You may be familiar with mapping applications like Apple Maps, Google Maps, and MapQuest. Further, you might have explored more complex interactive maps in popular news outlets like the New York Times and the Washington Post. The purpose of this study is to learn how we should create interactive maps that depict people.

Instructions
  • In Part 1, you will be presented with a case study. After you read the case study, you will be given an interactive map and a task. You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Questions include multiple choice, ranking, and short answer. We are particularly interested in your short answer responses, so please take your time when writing your answers.
  • In Part 2, you will be presented with a second case study. After you read the second case study, you will be given an interactive map and a task. You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Again, questions include multiple choice, ranking, and short answer, and we are particularly interested in your short answer responses. Please take your time when writing your answers.
  • In Part 3, you will be given a series of interactive maps and will be asked to rank them by provided criteria.
You will be compensated after completing these three sections and an exit survey!

Interactive Maps
Each interactive map allows you to Zoom, Pan, and Retrieve Additional Information in Pop Ups. The animations below demonstrate how to zoom, pan, and retrieve pop ups from the interactive maps. Please review these animations before proceeding.

Zoom
Zoom or change scales on the map by clicking on the map, scrolling with your mouse, or using the + and - widgets in the left corner of the map. View the animation below for an example.



Pan
Pan or navigate around the map by clicking on the map and dragging your mouse. View the animation below for an example.



Retrieve Additional Information in Pop Ups
Retrieve stories and data by clicking on the features or thematic layers on the map. View the animation below for an example.

Eligibility
Before beginning, please review your eligibility for participating in the study. These restrictions greatly impact your responses.
  • You must be 18 years of age or older.
  • You must be fluent in English.
  • You must currently be living in the United States.
  • You must complete the survey on a non-mobile device, such as a laptop or desktop computer. Completing the experiment on a smartphone or small screen tablet will greatly impact your performance and bias results.
If you have read the instructions and confirm that you are eligible, select 'Next' below to begin.

blocks.title: Oakland Case Study Introduction
blocks.ask:
In the past three years, a number of police killings in the United States have received widespread media attention, sparking national debates on law enforcement practices. The killing of unarmed black men in particular has given rise to massive protests and activist movements across the country. The killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Eric Garner in New York City, Walter Scott in South Carolina, and Freddie Gray in Baltimore, to name a few, all received sustained media attention. Statistics on police killings in the United States, however, are not recorded by the government.

In response, some journalists began investigating the extent of the issue. Media outlets like the Washington Post and the Guardian (United Kingdom) have began to compile statistics on police killings using public records, news reports, and crowdsourcing. The Guardian estimates that over 1000 people were killed by police in both 2015 and 2016. James Comey, the former head of the FBI, said that it was 'embarrassing and ridiculous' that media sources had better information on this issue than the US Government. California, the most populous state, leads the nation in killings by police. In Oakland, California, one of the largest cities in California, an estimated 104 people were killed by police between 2000 and 2017.

blocks.title: Aleppo Case Study Introduction
blocks.ask:
Since March of 2011, Syria has faced civil unrest leading to what the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) calls 'the biggest humanitarian emergency of our era.' Peaceful protests began in early 2011 after a group of teenagers were detained and tortured for painting revolutionary propaganda publically in the city of Dar’a. The situation quickly escalated with violent backlash from the Syrian government under President Bashar al-Assad. The backlash committed by the Assad government has prompted a Syrian civil war leading to over 400,000 lives lost, five million registered refugees, and six million internally displaced in Syria.

Prior to the conflict, Aleppo was Syria’s largest city and the heart of Syrian finance and industry. Since 2012, Aleppo has become a focal point and key battleground site throughout the duration of the conflict. Strict divisions between Assad regime-controlled areas and opposition-controlled areas quickly emerged. Bombing between both sides has destroyed crucial infrastructure such as homes, schools, and hospitals, killing thousands of people throughout the city. Over 100,000 civilians remained trapped in Aleppo as violence steadily increased in late 2016.

blocks.title: Part 1
blocks.ask:
In Part 1, you will be presented with a case study. After you read the case study, you will be given an interactive map and a task. You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Questions include multiple choice, ranking, and short answer. We are particularly interested in your short answer responses, so please take your time when writing your answers.

Remember: You can pan and zoom the map as well as retrieve additional information through pop ups by clicking on map features (i.e., points, icons, and polygons).

blocks.title: Part 2
blocks.ask:
In Part 2, you will be presented with a second case study. After you read the second case study, you will be given an interactive map and a task. You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Again, questions include multiple choice, ranking, and short answer, and we are particularly interested in your short answer responses. Please take your time when writing your answers.

Remember: You can pan and zoom the map as well as retrieve additional information through pop ups by clicking on map features (i.e., points, icons, and polygons).

blocks.title: Part 3
blocks.ask: In Part 3, you will be given a series of interactive maps and will be asked to rank them by provided criteria.

blocks.title: Exit Survey
blocks.ask: Please complete this exit survey to receive compensation.

blocks.title: Oakland Case Study (scroll to view all questions)

blocks.ask: In order to monitor interactions between police and Oakland residents, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) is developing plans for a police oversight center in the city. This center will allow for the quick deployment of legal observers to incidents involving the police. These observers will be called on to act as witnesses in legal cases while generating valuable data for the city to assess law enforcement practices. The ACLU has proposed potential locations for the center.
1. Using the map legend above, the five potential sites, and the distribution of people killed provided in the interactive map, determine which location would be best suited for the new center.
2. Rank each potential site from least suitable to most suitable.
Site 1 (1 = Least Suitable, 5 = Most Suitable)
Site 2 (1 = Least Suitable, 5 = Most Suitable)
Site 3 (1 = Least Suitable, 5 = Most Suitable)
Site 4 (1 = Least Suitable, 5 = Most Suitable)
Site 5 (1 = Least Suitable, 5 = Most Suitable)

blocks.title: Aleppo Survey Questions (scroll to view all questions)
blocks.ask: The words below describe different feelings and emotions. Please rank each word from 1 to 5 based on your current feelings and emotions after viewing the previous map. Rank each word based on the extent to which you feel the word right now.
Interested (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Distressed (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Excited (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Upset (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Strong (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Guilty (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Scared (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Hostile (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Enthusiastic (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Proud (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Irritable (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Alert (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Ashamed (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Inspired (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Nervous (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Determined (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Attentive (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Jittery (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Active (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)
Afraid (1 = Very Slightly or Not at All, 2 = A Little, 3 = Moderately, 4 = Quite a Bit, 5 = Extremely)

blocks.title: Aleppo Survey Questions

blocks.ask: 1. Who was included in the map? Is there a particular person or group of people that stood out to you, and why?
2. How do you feel about the people in the map? Did your emotional state change while looking and interacting with the map?

3. Were the people in the map relatable or not relatable (i.e., you can put yourself in their position)? Please explain your reasoning. How could the map be improved to make the people in the map more relatable?

blocks.title: Aleppo Survey Questions (scroll to view all questions)

blocks.ask: 1. What was the map about?
2. You were asked to select the most suitable site for a UNHCR emergency relief center. How did you decide on a site? Describe your decision making process.
3. How useful were the following map features?
Zooming (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Panning (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Retrieve Pop ups (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Map Symbols Depicting Locations of Deaths (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Map Symbols Depicting Potential Sites (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Legend (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Background Map (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)

blocks.title: Aleppo Survey Questions

blocks.ask: 1. Who was included in the map? Is there a particular person or group of people that stood out to you, and why?
2. How do you feel about the people in the map? Did your emotional state change while looking and interacting with the map?

3. Were the people in the map relatable or not relatable (i.e., you can put yourself in their position)? Please explain your reasoning. How could the map be improved to make the people in the map more relatable?

blocks.ask: 1. Who was included in the map? Is there a particular person or group of people that stood out to you, and why?
2. How do you feel about the people in the map? Did your emotional state change while looking and interacting with the map?

3. Were the people in the map relatable or not relatable (i.e., you can put yourself in their position)? Please explain your reasoning. How could the map be improved to make the people in the map more relatable?

blocks.title: Oakland Survey Questions (scroll to view all questions)

blocks.ask: 1. What was the map about?
2. You were asked to select the most suitable site for a ACLU police oversight center. How did you decide on a site? Describe your decision making process.
3. How useful were the following map features?
Zooming (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Panning (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Retrieve Pop ups (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Map Symbols Depicting Locations of Deaths (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Map Symbols Depicting Potential Sites (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Legend (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)
Background Map (1 = Slightly Useful, 5 = Extremely Useful)

blocks.title: Map Preference Survey
blocks.ask:
Rank the following maps based on your preference. Drag each block to reorder. (1 = Most Preferred, 4 = Least Preferred)

Note: It may take a second or two to load all images.

blocks.title: Map Preference Survey
blocks.ask:
Rank the following maps based on relatability (i.e., you can put yourself in their position). Drag each block to reorder. (1 = Most Relatable, 4 = Least Relatable)

Note: It may take a second or two to load all images.

blocks.ask: Which map style do you prefer?

blocks.title: Map Preference Survey
blocks.ask: Which pop up layout do you prefer?

blocks.title: Exit Survey (scroll to view all questions)
blocks.ask: Thank you for completing Parts 1, 2, and 3 of this survey. You will be compensated after completing an exit survey (4 sets of questions).
What is your age range?
What is your gender identity?
Please specify your race / ethnicity.
What is the highest degree or level of school you have completed?
If you have completed a postsecondary degree, what is your background discipline or disciplines?
Is English your first language?
Are you fluent in English?
Do you currently live in the United States?
If you live in the United States, what state do you currently live in?
Which of the following best describes where you live?
Do you have corrected vision?

options.text: Yes, I currently wear glasses and contacts

blocks.ask: Do you have color blindness or color vision impairment?
Did you complete this survey on a laptop or desktop computer?

blocks.title: Exit Survey
blocks.ask:
Please rate your familiarity or knowledge of the following topics.
(1 = Slightly Familiar and 5 = Extremely Familiar)

Please rate your familiarity or knowledge of the following topics.
(1 = Slightly Familiar and 5 = Extremely Familiar)

blocks.title: Exit Survey
blocks.ask:
Please rate your interest in the following topics.
(1 = Slightly Interested and 5 = Extremely Interested)

Please rate your interest in the following topics.
(1 = Slightly Interested and 5 = Extremely Interested)

blocks.title: Exit Survey
blocks.ask: Please rank the following: (scroll to view all questions)
Should the US create new programs to combat racial inequities?
Should the US decrease funding for existing programs that combat racial inequities?
Should the US create new social programs for incoming immigrants?
Should the US decrease funding for existing social programs that help incoming immigrants?
Should the US create new programs for national security and military?
Should the US decrease funding for existing national security and military programs?
Should the US create new programs for social welfare?
Should the US decrease funding for existing social welfare programs?
Should the US create new programs for environmental protection?
Should the US decrease funding for environmental protection programs?

blocks.title: Thank you for participating!
blocks.ask: Your response has been recorded. To receive your payment, please enter the following code in the submission box on Turk.
Confirmation Code: XY374M
We will send your payment within one week.
Please close your browser to exit.

blocks.title: Overview, Eligibility, and Instructions (scroll down to review and continue)
blocks.ask:
Thank you for agreeing to participate!

Maps are used on a daily basis at unprecedented levels. You may be familiar with mapping applications like Apple Maps, Google Maps, and MapQuest. Further, you might have explored more complex interactive maps in popular news outlets like the New York Times and the Washington Post. The purpose of this study is to learn how we should create interactive maps that depict people.

Instructions
  • In Part 1, you will be presented with a case study. After you read the case study, you will be given an interactive map and a task. You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Questions include multiple choice, ranking, and short answer. We are particularly interested in your short answer responses, so please take your time when writing your answers.
  • In Part 2, you will be presented with a second case study. After you read the second case study, you will be given an interactive map and a task. You will use the interactive map to accomplish the task and answer a series of related questions. Again, questions include multiple choice, ranking, and short answer, and we are particularly interested in your short answer responses. Please take your time when writing your answers.
  • In Part 3, you will be given a series of interactive maps and will be asked to rank them by provided criteria.
You will be compensated after completing these three sections and an exit survey!

Interactive Maps
Each interactive map allows you to Zoom, Pan, and Retrieve Additional Information in Pop Ups. The animations below demonstrate how to zoom, pan, and retrieve pop ups from the interactive maps. Please review these animations before proceeding.

Zoom
Zoom or change scales on the map by clicking on the map, scrolling with your mouse, or using the + and - widgets in the left corner of the map. View the animation below for an example.



Pan
Pan or navigate around the map by clicking on the map and dragging your mouse. View the animation below for an example.




Retrieve Additional Information in Pop Ups
Retrieve stories and data by clicking on the features or thematic layers on the map. View the animation below for an example.

Eligibility
Before beginning, please review your eligibility for participating in the study. These restrictions greatly impact your responses.
  • You must be 18 years of age or older.
  • You must be fluent in English.
  • You must currently be living in the United States.
  • You must complete the survey on a non-mobile device, such as a laptop or desktop computer. Completing the experiment on a smartphone or small screen tablet will greatly impact your performance and bias results.
If you have read the instructions and confirm that you are eligible, select 'Next' below to begin.
